div1.head: Poem: The History of a Rose, by Emilie B. Lawrence, 1867
div1.p:
I wish I was a conspicuous
flower said a delicate pink Rrose
to one of its companions once, why
cannot I be admired as well as
other flowers, and as it said so,
it grew pinker and pinker with
envy. You would have thought that
it would have been very contented
in the little green house coverd with
word bine and ivy and the sun
casting its radient light upon
the window, allthough it was
not, I had rather live in the woods
and be a wild Rose and be killed
by the winter winds than to
live in here and not be
noticed. I want to travel said
the little Rose and live in a large
house and have every body
admireing me and say, Oh, what
a beautifull little flower, but as
it is I have got to stay in here
forever. It was very early the
next morning when the gardener
came to select the flowers to send
to the city, after he had gatherd a
few he came to the pink Rose,
can it really be me thought
the little flower, yes it was, so he
took the Rose put herit in the basket
to send with the rest of the flowers.
It was then a proud little thing
it was now going to live in a
place where flowers were scarce
and there it would be called
beautifull. While they were on there
way the sun was very hot but
the little Rose did not complain.
At last the gardener stopped and
a rich lady came out and of all of the
flowers she thought the pink Rose
the prettiest, she then carried it in
the house and brought some water
and watered it, Oh! how refreshed
it felt, then it began to rase its
little pink head, and they all
exclaimed in one breath Oh! what
a lovely little creature; I must
send one of its buds to my
sick friend said the lady,
I know she would appreciate
it, after a while the little pink
Roses had faded and the lady
was going to throw them a way
and her little girl said Mama
give it to me, and the lady
gave it to her not thinking what
she was going to do with it, and
when she asked the girl, she
said wait and see Mama,
and the next summer the
little girl with a happy look
carried her mama theto see the
Rose she was supprised to see it, and
the child was still happier when
she pre spyed a humming bird
nest in one of its branches, the Rose
was the child's delight until it
was killed by a larg snow storm.

Written Composed and written by
Emily B. Lawrence during the
session of 1867.
